channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Upcoming Apple privacy update has developers desperately seeking dodges
item.description: Developers look at invasive user tracking techniques before advertising rule change.

item.title: Study finds we’re already committed to more global warming—sort of
item.description: Accounting for spatial patterns ups the estimate, but details are crucial.

item.title: “Shkreli Award” goes to Moderna for “blatantly greedy” COVID vaccine prices
item.description: Moderna used $1 billion from feds to develop vaccine, then set some of the highest prices.

item.title: Last year reusable rockets entered the mainstream, and there’s no going back
item.description: “If Rocket Lab ever builds a new vehicle, it will fundamentally be reusable.”

item.title: Bucking Trump, NSA and FBI say Russia was “likely” behind SolarWinds hack
item.description: Trump has downplayed the mass compromise and Russia’s involvement. Underlings disagree.

item.title: In a parting gift, EPA finalizes rules to limit its use of science
item.description: On its way out, the Trump administration makes things harder for the next one.

item.title: Court says Uber can’t hold users to terms they probably didn’t read
item.description: Adding a link to a registration page isn’t good enough, court says.

item.title: This P2P car-sharing company has a plan to boost Black entrepreneurship
item.description: Turo partners with Kiva to provide interest-free loans to an underserved community.

item.title: Telegram feature exposes your precise address to hackers
item.description: Messenger maker has expressed no plans to fix location disclosure flaw.

item.title: COVID-19 contact-tracing data is fair game for police, Singapore says
item.description: Similar privacy concerns are part of the uphill battle for contact tracers in the US.

item.title: Birds of a feather flock together, but patterns change with the mission
item.description: Autonomous robot swarms with interaction rules for different tasks might be possible

item.title: OnePlus brings a 90Hz smartphone to the US for $180
item.description: It’s a cheap 90Hz phone, but sadly you’ll have to deal with a terrible update plan.

item.title: Waymo CEO: Building safe driverless cars is harder than rocket science
item.description: Company raised $3.2 billion last year, but CEO says the challenge remains huge.

item.title: DOSBox Pure for RetroArch aims to simplify classic MS-DOS gaming
item.description: Integration with Retroarch is great for Retroarch users, confusing for others.

item.title: Comcast data cap blasted by lawmakers as it expands into 12 more states
item.description: Data cap harms poor people and isn’t needed to manage network, Mass. reps say.

item.title: Saving video gaming’s source code treasures before it’s too late
item.description: Over 90 percent of pre-2000 gaming source code may already be gone.

item.title: Researchers make their own enzyme pathway to get CO₂ out of the air
item.description: Pulling CO₂ out of the atmosphere using life is slow. But we could make it faster.

item.title: Cryptocurrency stealer for Windows, macOS, and Linux went undetected for a year
item.description: ElectroRAT was written from scratch and was likely installed by thousands.

item.title: Nintendo’s Power-Up Band—a physical key to Japan’s upcoming Super Nintendo World
item.description: Hands-on with Nintendo’s rare, new collectible—and it’s full of theme park clues.

item.title: 2020’s most disappointing games, as led by Blizzard’s WarCraft III: Reforged
item.description: Plus five other games, though really, none is as bad as Blizzard’s year-long bummer.

item.title: There are an insane amount of cool space things happening in 2021
item.description: Yeah, we’re going to say it. We really think Webb is going to launch this year.

item.title: Hackers are exploiting a backdoor built into Zyxel devices. Are you patched?
item.description: Recently discovered account with admin rights is hardcoded into multiple device models.

item.title: Gwynne Shotwell talks about selling flight-proven rockets, Starship
item.description: “It was easier to sell ‘flight proven’ to customers than it was to sell Falcons.”

item.title: Synchronized violin players reveal uniqueness of human networks
item.description: It’s relevant to economics, epidemiology, traffic, and the spread of misinformation.

item.title: Ticketmaster admits it hacked rival company before it went out of business
item.description: Ticketmaster used stolen passwords and URL guessing to access confidential data.

item.title: Experts debate fiddling with vaccine doses as virus rages out of control
item.description: Could cutting or delaying vaccine doses help—or make things worse?

item.title: UK blocks Assange extradition due to suicide risk, poor US jail conditions
item.description: Citing Epstein death, judge says US prisons “will not prevent” Assange suicide.

item.title: Microsoft hints at coming “sweeping visual rejuvenation” of Windows 10
item.description: An October job posting seemed to shore up rumors of big UI changes in 2021.

item.title: Samsung is unveiling the Galaxy S21 earlier than ever, on January 14
item.description: Samsung’s Galaxy S21, and the US' first Snapdragon 888 phone, launches in 10 days.

item.title: Google employees kick off union membership drive for 120,000 workers
item.description: The new union is open to all types of Google employees, including contractors.

item.title: Ether soars above $1,000 as bitcoin sets another record
item.description: The value of all cryptocurrencies in circulation is more than $850 billion.

item.title: Peugeot shareholders say yes to merger with Fiat Chrysler
item.description: The new company is called Stellantis and is the world’s 4th-largest automaker.

item.title: Today is the last day to add to our record Charity Drive sweepstakes haul
item.description: Join over 700 Ars readers who have given over $51,000 so far.

item.title: SpaceX may try to catch a falling rocket with a launch tower
item.description: At first blush, this sounds insane.

item.title: Study: Folklore structure reveals how conspiracy theories emerge, fall apart
item.description: Rumors swirling around 2016 Wikileaks dump was glue that held “Pizzagate” together.

item.title: My green home: $90,000 in clean tech upgrades, $20,000 in tax breaks
item.description: I bought solar panels, a heat pump, a condensing boiler, and an electric car.

item.title: Tesla delivered a record 500,000 vehicles in 2020
item.description: Tesla needs to expand rapidly to justify its $600 billion market capitalization.

item.title: Archaeology is going digital to harness the power of Big Data
item.description: Combining traditional “pick and trowel” field work with a sweeping birds-eye view.

item.title: You can’t unsee Tedlexa, the Internet of Things/AI bear of your nightmares
item.description: From the archives: Teddy Ruxpin + Arduino + Raspberry Pi + Alexa = What could go wrong?

item.title: Pandemic shaming can backfire—here’s a better way
item.description: Opinion: If we can’t expect people to avoid risk, we should embrace harm reduction.

item.title: How electric lighting changed our sleep, and other stories in materials science
item.description: Author and science evangelist Ainissa Ramirez discusses her book, The Alchemy of Us
